<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 171, 293]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 293]]<|/det|> **9702/33** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 314]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 **October/November 2017** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 322, 905, 335]]<|/det|> **2 hours** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 354]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 584, 374]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 392, 388, 406]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 719, 434]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 329, 448]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 504, 463]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 476]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 490]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 274, 516]]<|/det|> Answer **both** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 781, 530]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of one hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 905, 559]]<|/det|> You are expected to record all your observations as soon as these observations are made, and to plan the presentation of the records so that it is not necessary to make a fair copy of them. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 740, 574]]<|/det|> You are reminded of the need for good English and clear presentation in your answers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 586, 359, 600]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 600, 769, 615]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 626, 808, 640]]<|/det|> Additional answer paper and graph paper should be used only if it becomes necessary to do so. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 652, 604, 666]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 759, 680]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 724, 905, 852]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 875, 665, 890]]<|/det|> This document consists of 12 printed pages. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 897, 593, 927]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 903, 230, 913]]<|/det|> DC (ST/SG) 133401/3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 914, 190, 924]]<|/det|> © UCLES 2017 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[819, 914, 905, 927]]<|/det|> [Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 739, 91]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 94, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 695, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the rotational motion of a mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 836, 152]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass hanger and several \(10\mathrm{g}\) slotted masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 510, 183]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 191, 715, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 567, 532, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 920, 633]]<|/det|>
Adjust the string so that the distance between the bottom of the wooden blocks and the top of the mass hanger is \(40.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 789, 664]]<|/det|>
The combined mass \(m\) of the mass hanger and slotted masses must be \(70 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
Twist the mass through **ten** complete turns as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 100, 578, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 262, 512, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 293, 181, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 293, 875, 342]]<|/det|>
When the mass is released, it will rotate one way and then rotate the other way. This motion will continue until the mass comes to rest. At this point, the mass will continue to swing slightly with very little rotation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 355, 875, 389]]<|/det|>
Release the mass. Measure and record the time \(a\) taken for the mass to come to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 494, 875, 512]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 526, 180, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 875, 560]]<|/det|>
Change the distance between the bottom of the wooden blocks and the top of the mass hanger to 20.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 572, 180, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 310, 591]]<|/det|>
Repeat (b)(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 603, 875, 636]]<|/det|>
Release the mass. Measure and record the time \(b\) taken for the mass to come to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 790, 876, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 181, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 821, 875, 855]]<|/det|>
Change the distance between the bottom of the wooden blocks and the top of the mass hanger to 40.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
Change \(m\) and repeat **(b)** until you have six sets of values of \(m\), \(a\) and \(b\). You may include your results from **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 690, 138]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{a^2}{b}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 198, 945, 222]]<|/det|>
<label>□</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 245, 945, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>□</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 275, 945, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>□</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 301, 945, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>□</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 325, 945, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>□</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 504, 876, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 144, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 549, 176, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 545, 660, 574]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{a^2}{b}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(m\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 551, 876, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 583, 180, 601]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 581, 457, 601]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 583, 876, 601]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 613, 181, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 608, 632]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 845, 871, 863]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 876, 871, 895]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 893, 876, 912]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 749, 92]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(a\), \(b\) and \(m\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 97, 534, 126]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a^2}{b} = Pm + Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 403, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 680, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(d)(iii)**, determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 346, 198]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 252, 944, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[787, 350, 875, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 72, 715, 91]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 866, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a metre rule supported by springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 133, 546, 152]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 158, 757, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 514, 509, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 819, 564]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of the bosses until the metre rule is parallel to the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 577, 875, 611]]<|/det|>
The loops of string supporting the rule should be vertical and as close to the ends of the rule as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 624, 517, 641]]<|/det|>
The distance between these loops is \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 654, 181, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 654, 383, 672]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 732, 875, 750]]<|/det|>
<form>c = ............................................ $cm$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 771, 91]]<|/det|>
Suspend a mass \(m\) of \(0.100\mathrm{kg}\) from the loop of string as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
The distance between the string loop below boss A and the string loop supporting the mass is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 556, 153]]<|/det|>
Move the mass so that \(x\) is approximately \(80\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 851, 183]]<|/det|>
Adjust the height of boss B until the rule is parallel to the bench as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 191, 781, 510]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 521, 534, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 823, 570]]<|/det|>
The lengths of the coiled sections of the springs are \(y\) and \(z\) as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 143, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 176, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
